user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSysStatVolume:
```c
int32 OS_FileSysStatVolume(const char *name, OS_statvfs_t *statbuf)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(name);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(statbuf);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)name, &token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl(&token, statbuf);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileSysStatVolume:
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
bool OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    const char *                  target = (const char *)ref;
    size_t                        mplen;

    filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL) == 0)
    {
        return false;
    }

    mplen = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));

    /*
     * The virtual_mountpt member should be a substring of the search target.
     * If this matches a basic substring check then it may be match
     */
    if (mplen == 0 || mplen >= sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) ||
        strncmp(target, filesys->virtual_mountpt, mplen) != 0)
    {
        /* not a substring, so not a match */
        return false;
    }

    /*
     * Confirm that the substring ends at either a directory separator
     * or the end of string  (so exact mount points also match).
     *
     * For instance consider a virtual_mountpt of /mnt/abc and searching
     * for target=/mnt/abcd - this should return false in that case.
     */
    return (target[mplen] == '/' || target[mplen] == 0);
}
...
int32 OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_statvfs_t *result)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *local;
    struct statvfs                stat_buf;

    local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    if (statvfs(local->system_mountpt, &stat_buf) != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    result->block_size   = OSAL_SIZE_C(stat_buf.f_bsize);
    result->blocks_free  = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(stat_buf.f_bfree);
    result->total_blocks = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(stat_buf.f_blocks);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not identify any direct assignments to function parameter variables in the remaining code fragments. Specific reasons why other fragments are not flagged:
- The body of OS_FileSysStatVolume does not assign to its parameters 'name' or 'statbuf'; it only passes them to other routines and uses them by value.
- OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl updates members of the structure pointed to by the 'result' parameter (result->...), which is allowed by the rule (modifying the object pointed to is permitted), and it does not reassign the pointer parameter itself.
- OS_ObjectIdRelease and the OS_ObjectIdTransaction* helpers operate on the object referred to by the token pointer (i.e. they may write through *token), which is allowed; there are no assignments to the token parameter variables themselves in the shown code.
- The OS_CHECK_* macros shown are checks that evaluate the pointer or string length and do not reassign the parameter variables in the provided definitions.
- The call to statvfs and subsequent copying of fields into the result structure modify the pointee, not the pointer parameter.
Accordingly, the only areas warranting further inspection for potential violation of Rule 17.8 are the fragments listed above.
